newsitem.title: USA: U.S. stocks slide from highs, NYSE lifts curbs.
newsitem.headline: U.S. stocks slide from highs, NYSE lifts curbs.

text.p: U.S. stocks fell back from session highs on Wednesday, as profit-taking cut into an exuberant rally triggered by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan's upbeat testimony to Congress on the economy.
The Dow Jones Industrial average, which surged yesterday after Greenspan's Humphrey-Hawkins testimony, then roared to a session high of 8148 on Tuesday, pared some gains.
It was up 27 points at 8089 after the New York Stock Exchange lifted its curbs on index-arbitrage trading.

"It's profit-taking, and the bond market is a little weaker," Jim Benning, a trader at BT Brokerage, said. "The market has had a wild ride for the past couple of weeks, so it is giving a little back here."
The Nasdaq composite index slipped from session highs, trading up 0.56 points at 1564.
The long bond was down 3/32 at a 6.42 percent yield.
